author: Maarten Mittner
title: JSE closes weaker as uncertainty reigns after Fed decision | Markets
text:
Picture: MICHAEL ETTERSHANK Related articles Bond yields edge lower on rand Rand stronger in late trade following US rate decision JSE takes breather after strong run THE JSE closed weaker on Friday following the US Federal Reserve’s decision to keep rates unchanged, resulting in widespread confusion and uncertainty as to the state of the global economy.
The JSE followed global markets lower, with the exception of China, as the Shanghai composite closed 0.38% higher on Friday.
After losing more than 1.75% in intraday trade, the all share recovered somewhat toward the end of the session.
The Fed highlighted receding global economic growth as one of the reasons why it did not hike. Despite upbeat US economic data, consumer inflation remains below 2%, rekindling deflationary concerns which had been worsened by China’s recent devaluation of the yuan.
This is likely to hit emerging markets more severely when the Fed eventually hikes rates.
The Dow was 1.11% lower at the JSE’s close with European markets dragged down by the firmer euro, which gained ground against the dollar following the Fed’s decision. The FTSE 100 was 0.98% lower and the Paris CAC 40 had lost 2.42%. The German DAX was down 2.74% after trading 3.33% lower earlier.
"Political risks in the euro area are rising at a time of uncertain global growth and increased stress in emerging markets," Barclays Research said in a note.
At 5pm the all share closed 1.03% lower at 51,044.60 with the blue-chip top 40 shedding 1.13%. Platinums dropped 1.46% and industrials lost 1.21%. Financials were 0.98% lower and resources ended the day 0.61% off. The gold index rose 3.65%.
Macquarie First South Securities analyst Elna Moolman said the focus has now shifted from the Fed to the Reserve Bank, which will decide on local interest rates next week.
"The pressure on the Reserve Bank to hike rates immediately has been reduced," she said.
The Fed’s decision is an important factor to be taken into account, given that it was motivated by weak and uncertain global growth.
"The Fed will probably hike rates at the December meeting."
If this is the case, it would mean that the Fed would still not have hiked rates by the time of the final meeting of the Reserve Bank’s monetary policy committee meeting in November.
"The Reserve Bank will probably only hike rates in 2016 by a further 25 basis points," Ms Moolman said.
Global mining group Glencore retreated a further 4.89% to R26.06. The share has been heavily punished on debt concerns following its recent rights issue announcement.
Sasol was hit negatively by a combination of the stronger rand and lower oil prices, closing 3.25% off at R413.60.
SABMiller took a breather after its earlier run, closing 0.73% lower at R748.59 as the market awaits AB InBev’s takeover proposal next week.
Industrial conglomerate Remgro shed 1.75% to R248.46 following the release of results on Thursday indicating headline earnings per share rose by 20.3% in the year ended June.
Among gold stocks Harmony soared 7.87% to R12.20.
Platinum producer Lonmin’s woes continue, with the group’s shares shedding a further 2.39% to a low of R4.50.
Among banks FirstRand dropped 0.68% to R52.59.
Old Mutual ended the day 2.93% lower at R39.76.
Among property stocks New Europe Investments lifted 2.06% to R138.80.
Mondi closed 3.16% lower at R285.91. The company has acquired Germany-based Ascania for €54m.
